tn.text: Luke explains why he is writing to Theophilus.
The former book is the Gospel of Luke.

Luke wrote this book to a man named Theophilus. Some translations follow their own culture's way of addressing a letter and write "Dear Theophilus" at the beginning of the sentence. Theophilus means "friend of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: until the day that he was received up
tn.text: This refers to Jesus' ascension into heaven. AT: "until the day on which God took him up to heaven" (UDB) or "until the day that he ascended into heaven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The Holy Spirit led Jesus to instruct his apostles on certain things.
This refers to Jesus' suffering and death on the cross.

tn.ref: he presented himself alive to them
tn.text: Jesus appeared to his apostles and to many other disciples.
This event happened during the 40 days that Jesus appeared to his followers after he had risen from the dead.
Here the word "he" refers to Jesus. Except where otherwise noted, the word "you" in the book of Acts is plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_youdual]])

tn.ref: When he was meeting together with them
tn.text: "When Jesus was meeting together with his apostles"
This is a reference to the Holy Spirit. AT: "the Holy Spirit, whom the Father promised to send" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
If you translated the previous phrase to include the words "Holy Spirit," you can change the word "which" to "whom." AT: "about whom Jesus said"

tn.ref: John indeed baptized with water ... baptized in the Holy Spirit
tn.text: Jesus contrasts how John baptized people in water with how God would baptize believers in the Holy Spirit.
"John indeed baptized people with water"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will baptize you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here the word "they" refers to the apostles.

tn.ref: is this the time you will restore the kingdom to Israel
tn.text: "will you now make Israel a great kingdom again"

Possible meanings are 1) the words "times" and "seasons" refer to different kinds of time. AT: "the general period of time or the specific date" or 2) the two words are basically synonymous. AT: "the exact time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: you will receive power ... and you will be my witnesses
tn.text: The apostles will receive power that will enable them to be witnesses for Jesus. AT: "God will empower you ... to be my witnesses"

tn.ref: to the ends of the earth
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "all over the world" or 2) "to the places on earth that are farthest away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"as they watched." The apostles "were looking up" at Jesus because Jesus rose into the sky. AT: "as they were looking up at the sky" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "he rose up into the sky" or "God raised him up into the sky" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: a cloud hid him from their eyes
tn.text: "a cloud blocked their view so that they could no longer see him"
"staring at the sky" or "gazing at the sky"
The angels address the apostles as men who are from Galilee.

tn.ref: will return in the same manner
tn.text: Jesus will return in the sky, just as clouds covered him when he arose into heaven.
"The apostles returned"
This refers to the distance which, according to Rabbinical tradition, a person was allowed to walk on a Sabbath day. AT: "about one kilometer away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"When they reached their destination." Verse 12 says they were returning to Jerusalem.
"the room on the upper level of the house"

tn.ref: They were all united as one
tn.text: This means that the apostles and believers there all shared a common commitment and purpose, and there was no strife among them.

tn.ref: as they diligently continued in prayer
tn.text: This means that the disciples prayed together regularly and frequently.
This event happened during the time that Peter and the other believers were staying together in the upper room.

These words mark the beginning of a new part of the story. They refer to the period of time after Jesus ascended while the disciples were meeting in the upper chamber. AT: "During that time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])

tn.ref: in the midst of the brothers
tn.text: Here the word "brothers" refers to fellow believers and includes both men and women.

tn.ref: it was necessary that the scripture should be fulfilled
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the things that we read about in scripture had to take place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The word "mouth" refers to the words that David wrote. AT: "through the words of David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
In verse 17 Peter continues his speech to the believers that he began in [[:en:bible:notes:act:01:15|1:16]].

In verses 18-19 the author tells the reader background information about how Judas died and what people called the field where he died. This is not part of Peter's speech. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
Although Peter is addressing the entire group of people, here the word "us" refers only to the apostles. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
The words "this man" refers to Judas Iscariot.

tn.ref: the earnings he received for his wickedness
tn.text: "the money that he earned from the evil thing that he did." The words "his wickedness" refer to Judas Iscariot's betraying Jesus to the people who killed him. (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: there he fell headfirst, and his body burst open, and all his intestines poured out
tn.text: This suggests that Judas fell from a high place, rather than just falling down. The fall was severe enough to cause his body to burst open. Other passages of scripture mention that he hanged himself. (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
When the people living in Jerusalem heard of the way in which Judas died, they renamed the field.
Peter continues his speech to the believers that he began in [[:en:bible:notes:act:01:15|1:16]].
Based on the situation with Judas that Peter just recounted, he recalls two Psalms of David that relate to the incident. The quote ends at the end of this verse.

tn.ref: For it is written in the Book of Psalms
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "For David wrote in the Book of Psalms" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Let his field be made desolate, and do not let even one person live there
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Let his field be made desolate
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) that the word "field" refers to the field where Judas died or 2) that the word "field" refers to Judas's dwelling place and is a metaphor for his family line. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"become empty"
Peter finishes his speech to the believers that he began in [[:en:bible:notes:act:01:15|1:16]].
Here the word "us" refers to the apostles and does not include the audience to whom Peter is speaking. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
Based on the scriptures that he quoted and on what Judas had done, Peter tells the group what they must do.

tn.ref: one of the men who accompanied us ... must be a witness with us of his resurrection
tn.text: Peter lists the qualifications for the man who is to replace Judas as an apostle.

tn.ref: the Lord Jesus went in and out among us
tn.text: "the Lord Jesus lived among us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: beginning from the baptism of John
tn.text: Possible meanings: 1) "beginning from when John baptized Jesus" or 2) "beginning from when John baptized people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: to the day that he was taken up from us
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "until the day when Jesus left us and rose up to heaven" (UDB) or "until the day that God took him up from us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here the word "They" refers to all of the believers who were present. AT: "They proposed two men who fulfilled the requirements that Peter listed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Joseph called Barsabbas, who was also named Justus
tn.text: Barsabbas was Joseph's surname or last name, but people also called him Justus. AT: "Joseph Barsabbas, whom people also called Justus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

Here the word "They" refers to all of the believers, but it was probably one of the apostles who spoke these words. AT: "The believers prayed together and one of the apostles said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: You, Lord, know the hearts of all people
tn.text: Here the word "hearts" refers to the thoughts and motives. AT: "You, Lord, know the thoughts and motives of everyone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: to take the place in this ministry and apostleship
tn.text: Here the word "apostleship" defines what kind of "ministry" this is. AT: "to take Judas' place in this apostolic ministry" or "to take Judas' place in serving as an apostle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Here the word "transgressed" means that Judas turned aside from, or stopped performing, this ministry. AT: "from which Judas turned aside"

tn.ref: to go to his own place
tn.text: This phrase refers to Judas' death and likely to his judgment after death. AT: "to go where he belongs" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
The apostles cast lots to decide between Joseph and Matthias.
The lot indicated that Matthias was the one to replace Judas.

tn.ref: he was numbered with the eleven apostles
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the believers considered him to be an apostle with the other eleven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
